Euphorbia serpens Kunth
in Humboldt et al. , Nov. Gen. Sp. 2(5): 52. 1817.

Anisophyllum serpens (Kunth) Klotzsch & Garcke
in

â‰¡
Chamaesyce serpens (Kunth) Millspaugh
in
Parish (1913: 6)
, isonym

subSubSection.paragraph: Description :â€”Herbs, annual, with slender taproot. Stems prostrate, mat-forming and rooting at nodes, 15â€“50 cm , glabrous. Leaves opposite; stipules connate, deltate, white to pink, membranaceous, 0.5â€“1.0(â€“1.2) mm, glabrous; petiole less than 1 mm , glabrous; blade ovate or orbiculate, 2â€“7(â€“9) Ã— 2â€“6 mm , base asymmetric, rounded to subcordate, margins entire, apex rounded, usually retuse, surfaces glabrous; only midvein conspicuous. Cyathia solitary at distal nodes; peduncle 0.5â€“1.0(â€“2.5) mm. Involucre campanulate to turbinate, 0.3â€“0.7(â€“1.0) Ã— 0.4â€“0.6 mm , glabrous; glands 4, yellow, oblong, 0.1 Ã— 0.2 mm ; appendages white to pinkish, forming narrow rim at edge of gland, 0.1â€“0.2 Ã— 0.2â€“0.3 mm , margin entire or crenulate. Staminate flowers 5â€“10. Pistillate flowers: ovary glabrous; styles 0.2 mm , 2-fid Â½ to nearly entire length. Capsules broadly ovoid or subglobose, 1.3â€“1.4 Ã— 1.3â€“1.7 mm , glabrous; columella (0.9â€“)1.0â€“ 1.2 mm . Seeds white to grey or pinkish, ovoid, slightly 3â€“4-angled in cross section, 0.7â€“1.1 Ã— 0.4â€“0.7 mm , smooth.
Ecology :â€”Accidentally dispersed by humans and other animals, including livestock, as contaminant; globally considered as weed of cereals, orchards, plantations, vegetables, roadsides and pastures.

Taxonomic annotations :â€”The synonymy
E. serpens var. montevidensis Casar. ex Boissier
reported in
Galasso et al. (2018a)
is erroneous. In fact, the name
E. serpens var. montevidensis (Boiss.) Cabrera (1953: 284)
is validely published, but is a synonym of
E. klotzschii Oudejans (1989: 46)
.
Euphorbia serpens
has been confused with
E. humifusa
in many cases, because of their shared glabrescence. However, the two species significantly differentiate in leaves and stipules morphology. Notwithstanding the subspecies rank is not considered as valid by some authors (e.g. WCSP 2018 , Steinmann 2014 ), other botanists (e.g. Verloove & Lambinon 2011 , Wolf & KirÃ¡ly 2014 ,
Lazzeri et al. 2018
) recognized two subspecies of
E. serpens
:
E. serpens subsp. serpens
and
E. serpens subsp. fissistipula
. Many authors (e.g. Jauzein 1989 , HÃ¼gin 1998a , Wolf & KirÃ¡ly 2014 ), together with different chromosome numbers, reported some morphological characters that allow indeed differentiating the two subspecies.

Chamaesyce radicans (Engelm. ex Boiss.) Millspaugh (1916: 411)

subSubSection.paragraph: Alien status :â€”Neophyte native to the New World, it can be considered naturalized in Italy . The first record for Italy date back to 1998 for LIG ( HÃ¼gin 1998a ). The first European occurrence is from 1842 for France and subsequently in Germany , Denmark , Belgium , United Kingdom , Spain , Portugal , Austria , Switzerland , Hungary , Italy , Greece , Cyprus , Bulgaria and Romania . It results as naturalized in many cases, especially in Mediterranean region ( SÃ®rbu & È˜uÈ™nia 2018 ; see also Haddad 2016 ).

b.

subsp. fissistipula (Thell.) Verloove & Lambinon

Euphorbia serpens var. fissistipula Thellung (1907: 755)

â‰¡
Chamaesyce serpens (Kunth) Small subsp. fissistipula (Thell.) HÃ¼gin (1998b: 223)

subSubSection.paragraph: Alien status :â€”Neophyte native to the New World, it can be considered doubtfully occurring in Italy . The only one record for Italy is for LIG by HÃ¼gin (1998a , see Taxonomic annotations). In Europe it is recorded also for Denmark , Belgium and France ( HÃ¼gin 1999 , Wolf & KirÃ¡ly 2014 , SÃ®rbu & È˜uÈ™nia 2018 ).

Occurrence in Italy
:â€”Recorded for LIG by HÃ¼gin (1998a) . We consider its presence in Italy as dubious (see Taxonomic annotations).

Taxonomic annotations :â€”According to the herbarium material examined, and as justified by the different chromosome numbers ( HÃ¼gin 1998a ), we consider the two subspecies taxa as valid. Most of European records refer to
E. serpens subsp. serpens
, while
E. serpens subsp. fissistipula
was recorded few times, in Denmark , Belgium , France and Italy ( HÃ¼gin 1999 , Wolf & KirÃ¡ly 2014 , SÃ®rbu & È˜uÈ™nia 2018 ). The presence of
E. serpens subsp. fissistipula
in Italy ( LIG ) reported by HÃ¼gin (1999) is based on data on chromosome numbers and is not linked to any herbarium specimen. Moreover, we did not find any herbarium material confirming the presence of this subspecies in the past in Italy .All the material we examined from Italy corresponds to
E. serpens subsp. serpens
. Accordingly, at the moment we could verify only the presence
E. serpens subsp. serpens
present in Italy (including LIG ), even if further investigations are required for an accurate distribution of these subspecies taxa in Europe.
